hint: A user action or system occurrence that triggers a response in a web application. It can include clicking a button, submitting a form, or receiving a message from a server.
Feature that reffers to the design of websites and applications to be usable by people with disabilities.
A piece of software that is required for another software application to function properly.
A user interface element commonly found at the top of web pages, containing links or buttons for navigating between different sections or pages of a website or application.
A CSS feature for creating complex animations by specifying appearance and behavior of elements at different points along a timeline.
An HTML element used to collect user input and submit it to a server for processing.
The part of a web application that is responsible for server-side operations.
The file which create a mapping between your source(original) code and your generated code.
The process of collecting all code, databases, assets and other parts of your project and launching them to an appropriate hosting environment to be accessed by the intended users.
Commonly used web development approach that focuses on flexibility and adaptability, helping teams quickly respond to changes in strategy and requirements.
A program that checks for syntax errors in code.
A tiny icon included along with a website, which is displayed in places like the browser's address bar, page tabs and bookmarks menu.
Template definition of an object's properties and methods, the blueprint from which other more specific instances of the object are drawn.
The HTML element is part of HTML5 and allows for dynamic, scriptable images.
A function passed into another function as an argument, which is then invoked inside the outer function to complete some kind of routine or action.
A function, the main purpose of which is to implement reusable object creation code.
A special function that takes another function and alters its behavior.
The process of finding and fixing errors within a script.
A feature that allows inner functions to access the outer scope of a function.
A data that describes data.
The part of an representing the data manipulated by the operator.
Propagation of the event from a child element to its parent element
The process whereby the interpreter appears to move the declaration of functions, variables, classes, or imports to the top of their scope, prior to execution of the code.
Propagation of the event from a parent element to its child element
A base class for DOM which offers navigation through elements and search methods like getElementsById, querySelector.
A base class which represents any web page loaded in the browser and serves as an entry point into the web page's content, which is the DOM tree.
A tool which is used to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors and suspicious constructs.
Automated tool that helps to format source code automatically.
Data type that represents unique, unforgeable identifiers.
A sequence of characters in the code that identifies a variable, function, or property.
A layout model for displaying items in a single dimension â€” as a row or as a column.
A logical data type that can have only the values true or false.
A self-contained series of instructions to perform a function.
A piece of code (usually JavaScript on the Web) used to provide modern functionality on older browsers that do not natively support it.
A special piece of software that translates source code to another source code.
A programming language used most often for dynamic client-side scripts on webpages.
Data that is not an object and has no methods or properties in JavaScript.
An object that's returned by a function that has not yet completed its work.
The act of a function calling itself, recursion is used to solve problems that contain smaller sub-problems.
A named variable passed into a function.
The process of removing unnecessary or redundant data without affecting how a resource is processed by the browser.
Program that processes its input data to produce output that is used as input in another program.
Reserved syntax consisting of punctuation or alphanumeric characters that carries out built-in functionality.
